ICE noun
(US LAW)
[ S ] abbreviation for Immigration and Customs Enforcement: the US government department that is responsible for making sure that laws on who is allowed to enter, stay in, and work in the US and what is allowed to be brought across US borders are obeyed: The senator urged ICE not to deport the woman, who has four young children. In a raid by ICE agents on a clothing manufacturer, more than 100 workers were arrested on immigration-related offences.
More examplesFewer examplesNationwide, ICE has stepped up its enforcement, making 3,900 immigration arrests and 1,000 criminal arrests in the past 10 months.ICE is training sheriffs' departments to make immigration arrests, a practice that was banned until a recent federal law change. A check with ICE would have revealed that Martinez had previously been deported.He is assistant director of ICE Detention and Removal Operations.

ICE noun
(ON PHONE)
[ U ] abbreviation for In Case of Emergency: used as a name for a number stored on a person's mobile phone that other people should call if the person is seriously ill or injured: The idea of ICE took off after the 7 July 2005 London bombings. Some handsets provide access to a list of ICE contacts directly from the "locked" screen.
More examplesFewer examplesHe urged mobile phone manufacturers to add an ICE heading to contact lists of all new mobile phones.The ICE concept has been criticized because medical service personnel during an emergency normally do not have the time to contact relatives.
